{"title":"Section 2, Page 11","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"11
js( I will leave that to abler and more eloquent gentlemen.
2nd—The weather is too warm.
3d I think it more modest in lawyers (who have so many
opportunities of exhibiting their immense genius) to permit
those who are not of our profession to avail themselves of
occasions like the present, to present their practical in.
formation and local knowledge, which the planters have Ihe
best means of acquiring.
4th I have ever held it good policy in lawyers to pretermit some chances of spilling their overflowing eloquence on
their friends and neighbors, and to let their clients speechify
occasionally, so that, when they come to try their hands at
it. not finding it the funny and facile thing they look it to be,
but, on the contray, a very sweating undertaking, ihey may
llicnce come to appreciate, more highly, the labor of
those who speak for them by proxy or power of attorney. All,
therefore, that I now propose to do is, briefly to state the
reasons that impel me to submit these resolutions to your
more enlightened consideration.
And lirst, as to the first resolution, "that a railroad shall
be built from New Orleans to Washington, in the parish of
Si. Landry—"
I take it, that the fust part of this resolution, viz : that a
railroad shall be built, is already predetermined ; that it is
implied in the fact of our convening now and here. But it
appeared, to my humble judgment, meet and proper that
this, our determination, should be distinctly announced to all
whom it may concern. I might have worded it in a more
courtly and milk and water phraseology, and could have
said, "Resolved, that in the opinion of this convention, it is
expedient that a Railroad should be built," &e. But you
cannot build a road with milk, any more than you can make
a revolution with rose-water.","fullrs":{},"find":"2076.jp2","dmaccess":{},"dmimage":{},"dmcreated":"2012-01-18","dmmodified":"2012-01-18","dmoclcno":{},"dmrecord":"2075","restrictionCode":"1","cdmfilesize":"492597","cdmfilesizeformatted":"0.47 MB","cdmprintpdf":"0","cdmhasocr":"1","cdmisnewspaper":"0"}
